Your goal is to win chips and outlast opponents through strategic play.
Game Information:

- Starting stack: 1000 chips
- Blinds: 10/20

Here are examples of good poker decision-making:

Example 1: Pre-flop with pocket aces (A♠ A♥), facing a small bet. Action: '[Raise 50]' because pocket aces are the strongest starting hand and should be played aggressively to build the pot.

Example 2: You have 7♣ 2♦ (worst starting hand) and opponent bets big. Action: '[Fold]' because this hand has almost no chance of winning and continuing would waste chips.

Example 3: You have a strong flush draw on the flop, opponent checks, pot is 100 chips. Action: '[Bet 40]' to take control and potentially win immediately, or build pot for when you complete your draw.

Example 4: You're short on chips (only 200 left) and have A♠ K♦ facing a big raise. Action: '[Call]' or '[Raise 200]' all-in because AK is strong enough to risk your tournament life with a short stack.

  '[Bet N]'  - open for N chips
  '[Raise N]'- raise by N chips

Invalid actions will result in retries. Use exact bracket format and ensure you have sufficient chips for bets/raises. Check when facing a bet is invalid.

rounds.response:
I'm in the Big Blind with Q♣ K♠ facing an SB raise to 20 (standard raise to 2BB). This is a strong, offsuit Broadway hand that does very well against typical SB stealing ranges (often ~50 % of hands). It flops top-pair and big draws frequently, and has good equity even when dominated. Pots should be bloated now, not later.

Pot is 30, facing 10 to call. A simple flat-call is okay but risks going multi-way into the flop passively. Instead I’ll make a 3-bet to roughly 3× the open (60 total) to take the initiative and deny equity to weaker hands, while building value when ahead.

[Raise 40]

rounds.response:
My hole cards: A♠ 7♠  
Position: Small Blind (first to act)  
Stack: 1000 chips  
Blinds: 20 (I’ve posted the 20)  
Current bet to me: none, I can check or bet.

A♠ 7♠ is a decent ace-high hand with a flush-draw possibility.  
Playing from the SB, aggressive play usually wins small pots when opponent has junk.  
A standard small-ball play is to open-raise to around the size of the pot (30 chips), hoping he folds or we can out-play later streets if he calls.

Action: [Bet 30]
